displayed_text:
DOCTOR: Can you guys stop moving?

FAMILY MEMBER: We’re done.

DOCTOR: Oh yes, I’m just checking. And how is it? Do you love it?

FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah, it’s uh; we have to make some changes but yeah, it feels like home.

DOCTOR: That’s awesome, no ladders for you, right?

FAMILY MEMBER: I had to argue with him about it.

PATIENT: Could I give away all my ladders?

DOCTOR: Did you put it in the garage sale?

DOCTOR: I was going to do a drive-by and take your ladder.

DOCTOR: laughs & PAT chuckles

What race do you think the patient is? :: What race do you think the patient is? :::Unsure

displayed_text:
DOCTOR: Yeah, I mean it’s not a humongous spot. But it still is enough for it’s -

FAMILY MEMBER: Causing pain.

DOCTOR: Uh hum.

FAMILY MEMBER: I thought maybe he might have hurt his self when he was carrying boxes up and down stairs

DOCTOR: No, now we’re down now, though, right? No more.

PATIENT: Well, I don’t think it was so much carrying boxes because my kids and my wife wouldn’t let me carry weight.

DOCTOR: Yeah.

FAMILY MEMBER: But you did.

PATIENT: But it was, no but it was never a heavy weight. It was just, yeah, I did do a lot of up and down the stairs.

DOCTOR: Yeah.

DOCTOR: So it isn’t like he stands there and they only shoot it up like a bone injection.

FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.

DOCTOR: Uhn-uhn. You get an intravenous you know little catheter.

PATIENT: And that’s going to be in me for six months.

DOCTOR: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month.

FAMILY MEMBER: Does he have to keep that catheter in there for the whole month?

DOCTOR: No.

FAMILY MEMBER: Oh good.

DOCTOR: Like you put it in

DOCTOR: makes mimicking sound

PATIENT: So what makes you think I may have fallen again?

DOCTOR: Because I can’t, K just mentioned that she thought you did.

PATIENT: Oh.

DOCTOR: But it might have been last time.

FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.

DOCTOR: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before?

FAMILY MEMBER: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain.

DOCTOR: Where is your worst pain do you think?

PATIENT: Right here.

DOCTOR: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like.

PATIENT: Okay.

DOCTOR: Okay? And, chances we are going to have to put you on a medication called Zytiga.

PATIENT: Okay.

DOCTOR: Okay. This is a pill. These are pills that have a very good chance of working against the cancer.

PATIENT: Okay.

DOCTOR: And they will likely shrink the disease and, you know, also lower the PSA, and the good thing is they are likely to work for long periods of time.

PATIENT: Okay.

DOCTOR: But, the possibility of side effects is a little bit higher. Okay? And usually, those side effects are high blood pressure, leg swelling, low potassium. So, you’re going to have to monitor and stay with the visits because at least for the first few months, we’ll have to monitor you somewhat closer.

PATIENT: Okay.

DOCTOR: Once both of us sort of get comfortable, like we did, but you got too comfortable,
